\section{Discussion}
\label{discuss}
Overall, the proposed GINN hybrid model demonstrated robust stock market index prediction performance. It showed superior accuracy in the out-of-sample prediction tasks, surpassing all other tested models in most stock market indexes studied. However, upon further inspection, the performance of the GINN model may not be as dominant as it initially seems. There are many more aspects to consider in the performance of these models. 

Firstly, the performance of the GINN and GINN-0 model is qualitatively similar to the GARCH model, as expected. When the GARCH model struggles with the time series data, the GINN model and the GINN-0 model may also fail to yield accurate prediction results. This is illustrated in results from the Nikkei 225 (NIK) and the Hang Seng Index (HSI) datasets, where the TGARCH model and the GJR-GARCH model yielded low accuracy ($R^2 <= 0.1$) while still outperforming GINN, GINN-0, and GARCH. In the NIK dataset, the GINN-0 model ended up in third place, and the GINN and GARCH models placed fourth and fifth, respectively. The GARCH model's low performance led to the low accuracy of the GINN and GINN-0 models, which make direct use of GARCH. This reinforces prior work which demonstrates cases in which GARCH fails to make accurate predictions, and here those cases hinder the performance of the GINN model and the GINN-0 model \cite{franses_forecasting_1996, lee_are_1991}. Future exploration of GINN-like hybrid models should consider the use of other variants of the ARCH or GARCH-type models. 

As for the comparison between the GINN model and the GINN-0 model, the GINN model usually outperforms the GINN-0 model by a small but noticeable margin. Both models always yield better performance than the GARCH model. The GINN model's better performance could result from the fact that it learns market knowledge from both the ground truth volatility and the GARCH model. We are surprised that the GINN-0 model yields better performance than the GARCH model in some cases, even though it doesn't utilize ground truth volatility in the loss function. It is still unclear why a model trained to predict the prediction results from the GARCH model would outperform the GARCH model itself. The smoother curve and profile of the GINN-0 model compared to the GARCH model may suggest that the LSTM component of the GINN-0 model serves as additional regularization for the model, and result in a more consistent prediction. More work is needed to investigate the actual cause of GINN-0's performance gain over the GARCH model. 

Thirdly, it is noteworthy that the performance metrics used in the study may not be sufficient to picture the performance thoroughly. As mentioned previously, the prediction results from the GINN model are overly smooth compared to that from the GARCH model. It has fewer peaks and less extreme values, and lost some characteristics of the market. That somehow resulted in a better performance. It seems that the performance metrics used, the $R^2$, MSE, and MAE, tend to reward smoother prediction results. One explanation is that the less smooth models, e.g., GJR-GARCH and TGARCH, get it wrong with their variations. They over-predict and under-predict instead of taking the medium and smoothed path. Also, compared to more conservative and average-inclining values, the metrics used punish wrong and extreme prediction values more severely. Thus, when the predicted fluctuating volatility got offset by a few days from the ground truth, it could result in much lower scores even though the market trend it captures is correct. This helps explain why the seemingly more fluctuating GJR-GARCH and TGARCH models generally yield worse scores. In Figure 6, the GARCH model seems to capture the market trend better than the GINN model, with more pronounced peaks and dips, but it ended up with lower scores. This raises the concern of whether the current performance metrics are sufficient or even suitable for stock volatility prediction performance evaluation, and promotes the critical need for a further and more comprehensive study of the performance metrics in the future. 

The simulated GARCH process data results unveil more insights into the performance gain of the GINN model over the GARCH model. The GARCH model and the GINN model yield comparable performance in a time series that perfectly satisfy the GARCH process. This suggests that the superior performance of the GINN model in real-world stock market data could be a result of the GINN model capturing information in the market that doesn't satisfy the GARCH process and the GARCH model fails to catch. 

The residuals between the prediction results and the ground truth variance for the GARCH and GINN models are analyzed through their amplitude spectrum with the Fast Fourier transform (FFT) process, as shown in Figure 7. It is found that the residual of the GINN model has a higher amplitude of very low (long-term) frequencies while having a lower amplitude in the high-frequency ranges compared to that from the GARCH model. This shows that the GINN model is better at capturing daily or short-time volatility features with higher frequencies, while picking up less stagnated long-term features that could be inherently noisy and unpredictable.

  \includegraphics[width=\linewidth]{FFT.png}
  \caption{Amplitude Spectrum of the Residual of the GARCH and GINN models on the S\&P 500 Index (GSPC) data}
\end{figure}

Another thing that could affect the performance of the GINN model is the value of the weight $\lambda$. The current weight is selected because they result in the best average performance on a dedicated dataset to ensure the models generalizability. However, our testing found that some weight values could result in better accuracy in certain time series data. This leaves room for further optimization if only focusing on modeling a specific time series data. 

Lastly, all tested models did poorly in terms of prediction accuracy. One possible reason for that is the differences in the markets in the in-sample and out-of-sample time periods. The markets change over time, including the participants, regulations, and strategies in use. This may lead to the model learning relationships that are valid for older times but not for the new ages. Many unpredictable factors also contribute to market volatility, such as macroeconomic news, investor sentiment shifts, geopolitical events, and elements of market microstructure. Models based only on historical price changes may approximate volatility trends but have trouble forecasting precise volatility spikes or drops, which are often driven by these external factors. There are a multitude of sources that affect volatility in different ways, and the time series may not be autoregressive after all. The GINN model is a meaningful step toward accurate stock market modeling and prediction, but there is still much work to do before a model can accurately forecast future market trends, if that is at all possible. 

Overall, the new hybrid GINN model and the GINN-0 model showed promising performance in stock market time series prediction. They represent a new way of constructing a hybrid model. The GINN model combines the advantages of classic statistical models and modern machine learning models, learning from both the factual ground truth and the market knowledge acquired by the GARCH model. This allows the GINN model to have a better grasp of both general market trends and finer details, resulting in a highly accurate and generalizable model. The GARCH component of the GINN model also serves as an additional regularization in the loss function, working as a guard against overfitting, and improving the generalizability. 

\section{Conclusion}
This paper introduced a novel hybrid model for volatility prediction in financial markets, named GARCH-Informed Neural Network (GINN). The GINN model utilized both market ground truth and volatility prediction results from the well-known GARCH model in its model training. This helps the GINN model to capture both general market trends and finer details, and results in better out-of-sample prediction accuracy in stock market volatility prediction tasks. The GINN model is noticeably better than all tested competing time series volatility models. The novel hybrid model structure introduced here provides new avenues for the construction of models for general time series modeling and forecasting.

### Summary of Recent Advances in Stock Price Forecasting and Volatility Prediction

#### Title: Recent Advances in Stock Price Forecasting and Volatility Prediction

#### Introduction
Stock price forecasting and volatility prediction remain critical challenges in financial engineering and quantitative finance, with significant implications for investment strategies and risk management. Historically, these tasks have been approached using statistical models, such as Autoregressive Conditional Heteroscedasticity (ARCH) and its extensions, including Generalized ARCH (GARCH), Exponential GARCH (EGARCH), Glosten-Jagannathan-Runkle GARCH (GJR-GARCH), and Threshold GARCH (TGARCH). These models are adept at capturing the volatility clustering and leverage effects inherent in financial time series, but they often struggle to account for the complex, non-linear dynamics and interdependencies that characterize real-world stock markets. In recent years, deep learning models, particularly those based on Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) and Transformers, have been introduced to address these limitations. However, these models face challenges in effectively capturing momentary and cross-time correlations, as well as in adapting to varying market conditions. This summary explores three recent papers that tackle these challenges through innovative architectures and techniques.

The first paper introduces a novel stock transformer architecture, \frameworkname (Market-Guided Stock Transformer), which aims to model momentary and cross-time stock correlations and leverage market information for feature selection. The second paper proposes a Double-Path Adaptive-correlation Spatial-Temporal Inverted Transformer (DPA-STIFormer) that uses features as tokens to model time series and introduces a double-path approach to capture different types of correlations. The third paper presents a GARCH-Informed Neural Network (GINN) that combines the strengths of the GARCH model with an LSTM neural network to improve volatility prediction accuracy and generalizability. Each paper addresses specific challenges in the field, contributing to a more nuanced understanding of stock market dynamics.

#### Main Content of Each Paper

**Paper 1: \frameworkname (Market-Guided Stock Transformer)**

\frameworkname is designed to address the shortcomings of existing stock price forecasting models, which often fail to capture the momentary and cross-time correlations between stocks. The paper introduces a market-guided gating mechanism that rescales feature vectors based on the current market status, enabling the model to automatically select relevant features. This mechanism is achieved by constructing a market status vector $m_\tau$ that includes both the current market index price and historical market index prices, as well as market index trading volume. The vector $m_\tau$ is then transformed into a feature dimension distribution using a single linear layer and the Softmax function, which generates scaling coefficients for each feature dimension. These coefficients are used to rescale the feature vectors, emphasizing or diminishing the contribution of each feature based on its relevance to the current market conditions.

The architecture of \frameworkname consists of five main steps: market-guided gating, intra-stock aggregation, inter-stock aggregation, temporal aggregation, and prediction. The intra-stock aggregation step uses a single-layer transformer encoder to process the rescaled feature vectors and generate local embeddings that preserve temporal details. The inter-stock aggregation step computes stock correlations using a multi-head attention mechanism and aggregates information from other stocks to form temporal embeddings. The temporal aggregation step then queries from all historical temporal embeddings to produce a comprehensive stock embedding, which is used for label prediction. The model's prediction layer employs a single linear layer, and the forecasting quality is measured by the Mean Squared Error (MSE) loss.

**Paper 2: DPA-STIFormer (Double-Path Adaptive-correlation Spatial-Temporal Inverted Transformer)**

DPA-STIFormer is a novel Spatial-Temporal Transformer model that addresses the limitations of existing models by treating features as tokens and introducing an importance weight mechanism to better encode node characteristics. The model consists of multiple Double-Path Adaptive-correlation Inverted Encoders (DPA-IEncoders) and a single Decoder Block with Decomposed Fitting (DF-Decoder). Each DPA-IEncoder includes an Inverted Temporal Block and a Double-Path Adaptive-correlation Block. The Inverted Temporal Block models the time series of each node using features as tokens, while the Double-Path Adaptive-correlation Block adaptively aggregates information from both the feature and temporal paths and learns two different types of correlations through the attention mechanism. The model also introduces a gating mechanism to effectively integrate information from the two paths.

The Inverted Temporal Block processes the time series $x_i$ for an individual node by inverting the time series to get $x_i^{I}$, rendering the temporal sequence of each feature as a token. The model then uses a self-attention layer to learn correlations between multiple features and develop better representations of each node. The Double-Path Adaptive-correlation Block decomposes node encoding into temporal and feature representations, simultaneously extracting different spatial correlations from a double path approach. The model structure is optimized for prediction performance and includes a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) for decomposed fitting, which decomposes the prediction target into mean and deviation predictions.

**Paper 3: GINN (GARCH-Informed Neural Network)**

GINN is a hybrid model that combines the GARCH model with an LSTM neural network to improve volatility prediction accuracy and generalizability. The model divides the time series forecasting task into two phases: initial prediction and calibration. In the initial prediction phase, a GARCH model is used to predict the variance, and the LSTM component calibrates the prediction in the second phase. The model structure is identical to the LSTM model, with 3 LSTM layers and Dropout layers in between, followed by two linear layers, a BatchNorm layer, and a ReLU layer as the activation function. The main difference is that the GINN model uses both the ground truth variance and the GARCH predicted variance as regularization terms in the loss function, which is a weighted combination of the MSE loss between the ground truth variance and the GINN predicted variance, and the MSE loss between the GARCH predicted variance and the GINN predicted variance.

The paper also introduces a special case of the GINN model, GINN-0, which only takes the volatility prediction from the GARCH model for loss calculation. This model is trained to predict volatility results from the GARCH model, and it achieves high performance in out-of-sample prediction tasks. The GINN model and GINN-0 model are trained and tested on 7 representative stock market indices from different markets across the globe, and their performance is evaluated using the Coefficient of Determination ($R^2$), Mean Squared Error (MSE), and Mean Absolute Error (MAE).

#### Commonalities and Innovations
All three papers aim to improve the accuracy and generalizability of stock price forecasting and volatility prediction models. They each introduce novel architectures and techniques to address specific challenges in the field. \frameworkname focuses on modeling momentary and cross-time stock correlations and leveraging market information for feature selection. DPA-STIFormer introduces a double-path approach to capture different types of correlations and uses features as tokens to model time series. GINN combines the strengths of the GARCH model with an LSTM neural network to improve volatility prediction accuracy and generalizability.

The innovations in each paper are significant. \frameworkname introduces a gating mechanism that automatically selects relevant features based on market conditions, reducing the computational complexity of modeling stock correlations. DPA-STIFormer uses features as tokens to model time series and introduces a double-path approach to capture different types of correlations, enhancing the model's ability to handle complex, non-linear dynamics. GINN combines the GARCH model with an LSTM neural network to improve volatility prediction accuracy and generalizability, and it introduces a special case, GINN-0, which only uses the GARCH predicted variance for loss calculation.

#### Conclusion
The three papers presented in this summary contribute to the field of stock price forecasting and volatility prediction by introducing novel architectures and techniques. \frameworkname effectively captures momentary and cross-time stock correlations and leverages market information for feature selection. DPA-STIFormer uses features as tokens to model time series and introduces a double-path approach to capture different types of correlations. GINN combines the strengths of the GARCH model with an LSTM neural network to improve volatility prediction accuracy and generalizability.

The experimental results demonstrate that \frameworkname outperforms other stock price forecasting models on the CSI300 and CSI800 datasets, achieving 13\% improvements on ranking metrics and 47\% improvements on portfolio-based metrics. DPA-STIFormer achieves state-of-the-art results on four stock market datasets, showing superior performance in capturing spatial-temporal correlations. GINN and GINN-0 achieve high performance in out-of-sample prediction accuracy, beating other models in most test categories.

Future research could explore further improvements in stock correlation modeling and the use of market information for feature selection. Additionally, the performance metrics used in these studies could be refined to better capture the nuances of stock market dynamics and volatility. The hybrid model structure introduced in GINN provides new avenues for the construction of models for general time series modeling and forecasting, and future work could investigate the integration of other statistical models with deep learning architectures.
